comments:
Hi

I am following the tutorial for testing a Web service as explained on the WTP 
workbench tutorial below:

>>Using the Web Services Explorer to test a Web service 
  
>>  Launch the Eclipse WTP workbench. 
>>From the main menu bar, select Run -> Launch the Web Services Explorer . This 
>>will take a few moments the first time while Eclipse's internal Tomcat server 
>>starts up and loads the Web Services Explorer application. 
>>After the Web Browser view opens, maximize it. Result: 
 
and then I got this recurrent and permanent pop up window error:

javaw.exe Drive not ready
The drive is not ready to be used. Check the drive A: and verify it contains a 
disk
                 Cancel     Restart     Continue


Whatever action I am doing (Cancel, Restart or Continue), javaw.exe redisplay 
the error window until I cancel the process with the TaskManager that leads to 
the following new popup:

---------------------------
Eclipse
---------------------------
JVM terminated. Exit code=1073807364
D:\j2sdk1.4.1_02\bin\javaw.exe
-jar D:\Eclipse\3.1\eclipse\startup.jar
-os win32
-ws win32
-arch x86
-launcher D:\Eclipse\3.1\eclipse\eclipse.exe
-name Eclipse
-showsplash 600
-exitdata 86c_58
-vm D:\j2sdk1.4.1_02\bin\javaw.exe
-vmargs
-jar D:\Eclipse\3.1\eclipse\startup.jar 
---------------------------
OK   
---------------------------

Ther is NO drive A: on my PC (I replaced the floppy driver by a tape driver for 
backup) and I am not able to reproduce this prblem on a stand alone 
JFileChooser applet.

Regards


Francis ANDRE

The "JVM terminated" message is a normal consequence of killing the Eclipse 
Java process. As for the "Drive not ready" message, we've never seen this 
before. A few questions to help narrow this down:
1. Have you installed all the third party jars required by Web services?
2. I take it the message first appears precisely when you maximize the embedded 
browser (vs. maximizing the Eclipse window, or upon executing some other action 
after maximizing the browser)?
3. As another experiment, please try opening the embedded Web Browser and 
surfing to some basic Web site (like good old http://www.eclipse.org) and 
maximizing the browser. Does the same problem occur?
4. Finally, please start Eclipse with the -consoleLog option. When the problem 
occurs, issue a CTRL-BREAK from the console to produce a JVM Core file. In the 
file there should be a number of stack traces, one per active thread. Please 
either append these as remarks to the bug, or, better yet, zip up and attach 
the whole core dump file to this bug.

Thanks.

Hi

>> 1. Have you installed all the third party jars required by Web services?
Yes all of them

>>2. I take it the message first appears precisely when you maximize the 
embedded browser (vs. maximizing the Eclipse window, or upon executing some 
other action after maximizing the browser)?
No. I do not maximize or minimize any window. I am just starting Eclipse which 
leads to the main single workbench window, and then click to run and "launch 
the Webservice Explorer" 

3. As another experiment, please try opening the embedded Web Browser and 
surfing to some basic Web site (like good old http://www.eclipse.org) and 
maximizing the browser. Does the same problem occur?
Yes, the embedded web browser is working fine (see the catalina log at end) and 
the eclipse.org link works fine too.


4. Finally, please start Eclipse with the -consoleLog option. When the problem 
occurs, issue a CTRL-BREAK from the console to produce a JVM Core file. In the 
file there should be a number of stack traces, one per active thread. Please 
either append these as remarks to the bug, or, better yet, zip up and attach 
the whole core dump file to this bug.
I have try to get a code dump of the JVM by pressing CTRL-C but while I get the 
abort popup window of the JVM, I did not get the JVM Core file. Where should it 
be located (I presume in the eclipse.exe directory??)


By the way, I have made another experiment:
I erased the .metadata directory.
I lauched the Webservice Explorer
I answered "Cancel" to the java.exe many time
and finally I got the Webservice browser window with an 500 HTTP error

Re. your question in step 4, CTRL-C will kill the process. Instead, you need to 
press CTRL-BREAK. This is different than CTRL-C. It doesn't kill the process. 
Instead, it instructs the JVM to dump its core file out. You should get some 
information in the console window telling you where the core file is.

The exception in the Catalina log file will keep the Explorer from running, 
although I don't see any relationship between it and the "Drive not found" 
message you're getting. The exception suggests that wsil4j.jar is not present. 
Please double check that you copied "wsil4j.jar" into 
org.eclipse.wst.ws.apache.wsil_1.0.0/lib. Also, change into the lib/ directory 
and issue "unzip -l wsil4j.jar.zip */Abstract.class" and verify you get output 
like this:

Archive:  wsil4j.jar.zip
 Length    Date    Time    Name
 ------    ----    ----    ----
    525  11-01-02  12:59   org/apache/wsil/Abstract.class
 ------                    -------
    525                    1 file

Thanks - CB.

>  Length    Date    Time    Name

>     525                    1 file

I double checked: the wsil4j.jar is located at 
org.eclipse.wst.ws.apache.wsil_1.0.0/lib and the org/apache/wsil/Abstract.class 
is as identical as your input.


2/ Core dump of the JVM
Here is what is dumped on the Eclipse console

I think the problem is coming from the WinNTFileSystem method

"main" prio=7 tid=0x000357A0 nid=0xd10 runnable [7f000..7fc44]
        at java.io.WinNTFileSystem.getBooleanAttributes(Native Method)
        at java.io.File.exists(File.java:679)
I have check on the bug data base at java.sun.com and there are referenced bug 
related to this phenomenon (look at Bug ID: 5068218 "java.io.IOException: The 
device is not ready"during deployment for example)

Regards

Francis ANDRE

Created an attachment (id=18481)
webbrowser.jar with a bit of trace code

The stack trace suggests that one of the browsers found by
WebBrowserUtil.addFoundBrowsers() is at a path that's upsetting
java.io.File.exists(). I am attaching an updated webbrowser.jar for plugin
org.eclipse.wst.internet.webbrowser_1.0.0. It contains a tweak to the
addFoundBrowsers() method. It should produce a few hopefully useful entries in
the console window of the form "*** f = [filename]".

To update the jar:
1. Shut down Eclipse.
2. Backup org.eclipse.wst.internet.webbrowser_1.0.0/webbrowser.jar.
3. Save the attached jar to org.eclipse.wst.internet.webbrowser_1.0.0.
4. Restart Eclipse with the "-clean" and "-consoleLog" options.
5. Launch the Web Services Explorer and let me know what you get in the
console.

Thanks - CB.

I should also add that I highly appreciate your prompt reaction and precise 
guidance in solving this issue. If all opensource projet could have such care 
about problems, it would make the life of an integration team much more easy!!

Thanks

Thanks for your latest info. The lines of the form "*** f = [A:\Program 
Files\Internet Explorer\IEXPLORE.EXE]" would seem to be the cause. The 
WebBrowser plugin makes use of the JRE's File.listRoots() method to determine 
what drives (in the case of Windows) are available, and File.listRoots() is 
returning "A:\" as an available root. You might want to try writing a very 
simple Java main() that calls simple f.exists() for some File f constructed for 
pathname such as "A:\Program Files\Internet Explorer\IEXPLORE.EXE" to see if 
that reproduces the problem. If so, and listRoots() is returning something that 
exists() doesn't like, then this would seem to be a bug in the JRE related in 
part, perhaps, to the presence of your tape drive.

Let me know how that turns out. If necessary, another experiment we can try is 
to give you a patch to WebBrowserUtil.java that explicitly skips any paths 
beginning with "A:".

(Tim - since you're the WebBrowser guy, I'm copying you for a look at the last 
couple of remarks appended to this bug).

Thanks - CB.

Hi

As a matter of facts, the problem is coming from the WXP configuration that 
effectively was showing a A:\ drive. The fix is just to shutdown the A:\ driver 
in the hardware configuration of WXP and everything is working fine with the 
released wst jars.

Thanks for your help

FA

I really appreciated your help.

FA
